sideB.text: It is working now!
It's up and running!
It works now!
The system is operational now!
It is already working!

note:
[Up and running] is a professional idiom meaning a system is active and functioning correctly.

Use [Already] to emphasize something happened sooner than expected, while [Now] simply marks the current status.

sideA: Aún no está llegando el campo.

sideB.text: The field isn't coming through yet.
The field is not being received yet.
We aren't getting that field yet.
It's not getting the field yet.

note:
[Coming through] is a very common phrasal verb when discussing data streams or API responses.

Use [field] for JSON keys or database columns.

~It's not arriving the field yet~ ('Arrive' is an intransitive verb; you cannot 'arrive something'. Use [getting] or [receiving] instead.)

sideA: Hemos tenido algunos problemas con la intermitencia del backend.

sideB.text: We've had some issues with backend intermittency.
We've been experiencing intermittent backend issues.
We have encountered some flakiness in the backend.
We've been facing some intermittent issues with the backend.
We've been facing some issues with intermittency in the backend.

note:
[Flakiness] or [Flaky] is a very common developer term for something that works sometimes but fails others (intermittent).

Structure: [We've had] (Present Perfect) connects past issues to the present moment.

sideB.text: It hasn't updated yet.
It hasn't been updated yet.
The update hasn't gone through yet.
It's not updated yet.

note:
Use the Present Perfect [hasn't updated] for actions expecting completion.

[Gone through] implies the process was triggered but didn't finish.

sideB.text: Could you guys let me know when you deploy the purple package?
Could you notify me when the purple package is deployed?
Please let me know once the purple package deployment is done.

note:
Use [Let me know] as a friendly, standard way to say 'avisar'.

[Deploy] is the standard verb for releasing software.

~...deploy the package in purple~ (Incorrect phrasing: 'Purple' is the name of the package, so it functions as an adjective: [Purple package]. 'In purple' suggests physical color.)

sideB.text: Since what day has this been happening to you?
How long has this been happening?
When did this start happening?
Since what day has this happened to you?

note:
[How long] is the most natural way to ask about duration in English.

[Since what day] is grammatically correct but sounds more formal or specific to a ticket report.

~Since what day did that happen to you?~ (Incorrect Grammar: [Since] usually requires the Present Perfect tense because it connects past to present. Use [When] with simple past.)

sideA: Arreglé la query para que extraiga datos de Order Management.

sideB.text: I fixed the query so it pulls from Order Management.
I corrected the SQL to fetch data from the Order Management tables.
I adjusted the query to retrieve information from OM.
I fixed the query to get data from Order Management.
I fixed the query to retrieve data from Order Management.
I fixed the query to extract data from Order Management.

note:
Verbs for data: [Pull], [Fetch], [Retrieve], or [Extract].

[Fixed] implies repairing code that was broken or incorrect.

sideA: Estamos teniendo problemas con el proxy.

sideB.text: We are having issues with the proxy.
We're experiencing problems with the proxy server.
We are facing some trouble with the proxy.
We are having trouble with the proxy.

note:
[Experiencing] is a professional verb for status reports.

[Issues] is slightly softer and more common in tech than 'problems'.

sideB.text: Not directly one-on-one.
It wasn't a direct one-on-one interaction.
It isn't directly a one-on-one meeting.

note:
[One-on-one] (often written 1:1) refers to a meeting between two people.

~Not directly one by one~ ('One by one' means sequentially, like a queue. 'One on one' means interaction between two parties.)

sideA: Si necesito más información, como pasos o capturas, le pregunto a quien reportó por Teams de inmediato.

sideB.text: If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask the reporter on Teams right away.
If I require further details, such as reproduction steps, I contact the reporter immediately via Teams.
When I need more context, like screenshots, I reach out to the reporter on Teams instantly.
If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask the one who reported it on Teams.
If I need more info—like steps or screenshots—I ask who reported it on Teams.

note:
[Reporter] refers to the person who created the ticket/bug report.

[Right away] or [Instantly] emphasizes your responsiveness.

~I ask to who reported it...~ (Incorrect grammar: You 'ask someone', you do not 'ask to someone'.)

~...I ask to the one who reported it...~ (Same error: The verb [ask] takes a direct object. Correct: 'I ask the one...' or 'I ask the person...')
